title: SAVANNAH RIVER LANDING: What's up dock? More city bungling
text:
T he Savannah City Council quietly awarded a $648,000 contract last week to repair the floating dock adjacent to the Savannah River Landing site. The repairs will cost the city more than it contributed to the original construction of the dock about seven years ago. That’s outrageous.
The concrete floating dock was built with a $1 million state grant and a $200,000 city match. Since then, sections of the docks have been damaged by the wakes of passing ships.
Which raises the question, why was the dock, which has been closed to the public since it was built, ever constructed in the first place?
After being delayed by the 2008 economic collapse, the 54-acre Savannah River Landing site is expected to eventually be developed as investment returns to the city. Ongoing drainage improvements along President Street, which include access roads to Savannah River Landing and to another site across the street, are expected to help foster that development.
The dock rebuild consists of installing a type of dock designed to act as a weighting system to help prevent movement and future damage.
Also, the project includes removing and hauling away portions of the existing dock, including damaged sections that have since been placed on land adjacent to the river walk. Utility services pedestals for shore power are also to be installed by the contractor.
A fee will be charged for docking, as one is charged to boaters to dock along Rousakis Plaza. Although such fees are not a big money maker for the city, said city spokesman Bret Bell, they are appropriate as the users are paying for the service they’re receiving. With the first three hours of docking free, Bell said $15,603 was generated from the fee in 2014. Money collected from parking services will be used to pay for the repairs, he said.
City officials have been blaming the 2008 economic downturn for the stalled development of the Savannah River Landing site. Meanwhile, there’s a river walk that leads to nowhere east of the Riverfront Marriott. And, although not the city’s fault, that walk had to be repaired a couple of years after it was built. It now has weeds growing through the cracks.
In addition, the city has invested millions in infrastructure improvements to alleviate flooding along President Street and McIntosh Boulevard. The city hopes those improvements will encourage investment in Savannah River Landing.
The floating dock was not necessary to attract investors. It’s another example of poor long-term vision and a lack of common sense when it comes to real estate investment by the city.
It would have been more prudent for the city to land an investor, before spending taxpayer money for a dock nobody asked for and floated unused for seven years.
Didn’t the engineer of the designer or even anyone with a window on the back of City Hall consider the wakes created by the large container ships that cruise up the Savannah River past the dock wonder about damage caused by wakes? Apparently not.
Unlike the field of dreams, the city built the dock but nobody came.
